course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Nazism and German Society, 1914-1945
course.description: This course surveys German history from 1914 to 1945, with a focus on the rise, rule, and destruction of National Socialism. Topics to be covered include the First World War, the Weimar Republic, the emergence of the National Socialist movement, consent and coercion in the Third Reich, the racial state, Hitler's leadership, the Second World War, and the Holocaust. In addition to mastering historical concepts and narratives, students will sharpen their abilities to read sources and write analytical essays.
course.exclusions: HUMA 2589 (prior to 2018-19)

reviews.author: ahahahahahaha
reviews.title: Absolutely love the course
reviews.comment_content:
Before midterm: Mainly focus on how Hitler got into power, his ideology (you will have to read Mein Kampf which is a bit disturbing but quite interesting), his propaganda strategies, etc. You'll know more about how Nazis reach out to people and why people support them. The readings are very interesting.
After midterm: About how Germans were having discontent towards Hitler but chose to conform in some ways, Hitler's aggressive foreign policies, the WWII, the mindset of people who kind of 'help' the massacre.

Overall, really great course. I love all the assigned readings except for Allen's book (which is about a small town called Northeim). People at that time had interesting thoughts. I can relate it so much to modern politics (like rise of racism and white supremacy and even the protests in hk). I have to say that I do not like history that much in secondary school (did not study it in high school), but I'm always interested in rise of Nazism. If you want to know more about WWII, you'll enjoy the reading and get a good grade.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Derman is very kind. He is very knowledgable and if you ask something that he is not sure about, he will tell you honestly that he doesn't know (I love how candid he is). You can arrange an appointment with him about your term paper and anything you don't understand about the reading materials.
For half of the lesson time we are divided into an assigned group to discuss the questions he gave us. He'll give some explanations after the class discussion, which will help you revise and write your term paper.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation (Attendance and class discussion) 15%
Group presentation 15% (My group: 96/100, mean is ~90ish)
Term paper 30% (Me: 90/100, mean unknown, but I think I just got around mean :'(((( )
Midterm 20% (Me: 98/100, forget the mean)
Final 20% (Me: 100/100, mean unknown)
Overall, A

Midterm and final are really easy, open book with 70% MCQs and 30% identification question. Not sure if the TA just give 30% to everyone for their identification question, since I thought I didn't answer well. MCQs are just facts, so you can find it in the book. Identification questions are something like "Describe the few strategies Nazi Party consider for dealing with the Jewish Problem". You're given 3 hours to finish all, so you know you don't have to hurry.
reviews.comment_workload:
Presentation: Each student is only required to present for 5 mins, while there're so much to talk about on the topic. Even if all your groupmates freeride, you can still finish it. My groupmates are quite nice tho, we had two rehearsals before the presentation.

Class discussion: He'll assign you to a breakout room with your assigned groupmates after add/drop period. It's a good chance for you to discuss what you've read with your classmates and see if you miss out anything. Then when you go back to the main room he'll ask people to raise their hand and speak. I think most people spoke at least once in class discussion session. I would encourage you to speak as much as possible since he'll not accuse you of any wrong answer. You can check if you understand the materials correctly. Make sure you attend all the classes since attendance will be taken.

Term paper: Tbh it's quite easy if you attended all the lessons and understand the assigned materials. If you have any question, just ask the professor and you should be fine.

Reading materials: It's the tough part. I'll suggest you to read ahead in the early few weeks so that you catch up with the progress. If you can't finish it, you can split the readings with a friend (I did that, like I read half of the materials and wrote some notes and shared the notes with my friend) or just skim through the materials real quick. If you don't read the materials for some time it'll be hard to catch up (Im serious)
If you couldn't finish (which you really shouldn't), I would recommend you to at least finish Epstein's book (Nazi Germany: Confronting the Myths) as it gives you an overview of all the things that are happening.

reviews.author: qjk
reviews.title: Interesting course
reviews.comment_content:
About the history of Germany, all the way from 1871 (unification) to 1945 (end of ww2). The focus is mostly on ww1 and ww2 though.
Before the midterm, you will learn about the politics of the German Empire and the Weimar Republic (pre-Nazi) and after the midterm, you will learn about the Nazi regime and ww2.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Derman is a good teacher. Send your questions to him through email and he will answer them in detail and patiently.

Around half the lessons were lectures and half were discussions, where you had to do some reading and during the lesson, the professor would pose some questions and you had to discuss with your group in breakout rooms then after the group discussion everyone goes back to the main room and you can raise your hand to answer the questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Scheme:
Midterm 20%
Finals 20%
Term Paper 30%
Presentation 15%
Participation 15% (also counting attendance)

Me:
Midterm 100/100 Mean was ~84 if I recall
Finals 98.5/100 Mean Not Released
Term Paper 95/100
Presentation 91/100 Mean ~90
Participation Not Released, but I answered questions in around half the discussion lessons and attended all the lectures

Final Grade: A
I'm quite disappointed that I wasn't able to achieve an A+, considering I scored full marks in the midterm and near full marks in the finals.

I would say it isn't hard to get A range if you are hardworking and keep up with the readings, but A+ probably doesn't exist.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is inhuman, there are shit tones of reading to do each week, anywhere from 20 to 100 pages. I think on average there are 80 pages per week. If you fall behind on the readings you would be in big trouble.

The Term Paper took me a few days to write. We needed to incorporate knowledge from all the readings in the paper so I imagine you would be in big trouble if you skip the readings.

The presentation is done with your group (the same group assigned to you for the group discussions). You have to divide the work among yourselves so make sure to snatch all the good topics or else you will end up with the shittiest parts like me.

The good thing is the midterm and the finals are trivial. They are open book open notes, but no googling, and it is ok to just review the powerpoints the night before the exam. Some of the notes are in scanned pdf format where you can't ctrl-f search, so convert them into docx and back to pdf so you can ctrl-f search during the exam and save a lot of time.

reviews.author: #001/BULBASAUR
reviews.title: Came for the meme, left with historical insights and depression.
reviews.comment_content:
TL;DR: You will learn about things that happened before AND after Hitler's assumption of power. Take this into consideration before enrolling into this course for the meme (which I did).

- - - - -

This course will mainly go through the history of Germany during 1914 (the start of World War I) and 1945 (the end of World War II). It focuses not solely on Germany after the establishment of the Nazi regime (covered in the second half of the course), but also how the Nazi Party came to power (covered in the first half of the course). The history will be narrated from both macro perspective (such as how Germany in general invaded other countries using Blitzkrieg) and micro perspective (such as how ordinary Germans conformed to the regime and participated in killing innocent Jews).

There will not be disturbing images or videos (except for one or two shown in the textbook) depicting the war crimes committed by the Nazi party. However, some assigned readings were in fact case studies of typical Germans at that time period that might contain detailed descriptions of what actually happened. Sometimes they might induce a feeling of "what the f- is wrong with you".
reviews.comment_teaching:
TL;DR: You will have some lectures and many discussions through out the semester.

- - - - -

The classes consist of some lectures where Professor Derman essentially summarizes information from the textbook, and a lot of discussion sessions where you will be assigned to breakout rooms to discuss about the assigned readings. After each discussion session, Professor Derman would invite students to do some sharing. As a person who have actually finished all the assigned readings, I would say that the Professor's lecture slides are so well-summarized that it makes reading the textbook a bit redundant (though he would only publish the lecture slides after each lecture). The discussion and sharing sessions are also surprisingly useful because they usually cover most (if not all) main ideas of each assigned reading. These will prove very useful in your exams and term paper.
reviews.comment_grading:
This part of the review is BIASED AGAINST Professor Derman because I consider my overall performance as an extreme case.

TL;DR: It is not uncommon to get >90% in your assessments given how lenient Professor Derman is. This might be a sign of a competitive course grading.

- - - - -

- Participation: 15% (full attendance)
- Midterm exam: 20% (98/100)
- Group presentation: 15% (96/100)
- Term paper: 30% (94/100)
- Final exam: 20% (100/100)

I feel like this course's grading is fair considering it is a course offered in the University of Stress and Tension. Professor Derman is very lenient in grading our assessments and it is not uncommon to see yourself getting >90% for a given component. Because of this, the grading of this course might be competitive.
reviews.comment_workload:
TL;DR: Attendances are required. The exams are surprisingly easy and the term paper is not actually that demanding. Still, you will be doing a lot of reading.

- - - - -

Participation:
Actually, simply showing up in class is fine. Nothing to worry about.

Assigned readings:
This is the main source of workload of this course. You are (strongly advised) to read AT LEAST 60 PAGES of reading per week to prepare discussion. There would not be any immediate consequences if you choose not to finish the reading on-time. Still, you will need to read all those materials at some point before your presentation/term paper/exams.

Exams:
The exams consist of two parts: multiple-choice questions and "identification questions". The multiple-choice questions ask about trivial stuff so no pressure here. The identification questions are essay-type questions that require you to answer some sub-questions regarding to a given term (e.g. a certain organization, event, pact, etc.). These questions might be a bit tricky but, luckily, Professor Derman and his teaching assistant is very lenient in grading these questions.

Presentation:
After the midterm exam, your discussion group will be asked to give a 20~25-minute presentation to summarize how Hitler came to power (the first half of the course). The presentation is in fact not very demanding because there is literally an entire piece of assigned reading (which is also well-structured) on this matter. You might want to reuse this piece of material to make your presentation easier.

Term paper:
You are required to submit a 8-page term paper at the end of the semester, mostly about the second half of the course (Hitler's regime). Despite the 8 pages requirement, the term paper's workload is, frankly saying, not very terrible. You are required to format your text in a specific way that makes the paper at most ~2,500 words long. You are also only required to cite the assigned readings and extra-curriculum references are prohibited.

reviews.author: aashmanv
reviews.comment_content: The content is very thorough and easy to grasp if you have some kind of affinity for history. A bit needlessly detailed at times, but those details aren't really tested. The books studied are incredibly interesting but if you're not used to reading dense text it will be boring for you.
reviews.comment_teaching: Joshua Derman is a great teacher who will go out of his way to help you should you need it. He's a fun guy, although because the course is content-heavy the lectures can get boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
The midterm is mostly dates, facts, and key events.

The papers are very fun to write imo, and as long as you put thought into them and try to make novel points with reference to the books used in class you're good to go.
reviews.comment_workload: If you like the books, you'll breeze through them, otherwise reading 50 pages a week might seem like a chore. The papers are announced well in advance so don't procrastinate and you're good.

reviews.author: Paolo
reviews.title: This common core course is worth it
reviews.comment_content:
The course will cover everything about Modern Germany from 1918 - 1945. The emphasis will be on society during the interwars period.
How the aftermath of the First World War, and the constant political strife in the Weimar Republic paved the way for National Socialism and Adolf Hitler.
How the Nazi Party shaped German society during their rule.
How the Nazi Party tackled the economic problems and what their foreign policy was.
How the Nazi Party essentially created a racial state.

There will be 1 lecture and 1 tutorial, both 80 minutes, usually on a Tuesday and Thursday respectively.

Attendance will be taken at a random basis, its advisable to attend every lecture and every tutorial.

The tutorial will be a group discussion of students.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. DERMAN is an excellent lecturer. He elaborates the main points on the lecture slides very clearly and he is a funny teacher and would occasionally add humor to his lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm essay: 20%
Midterm paper: 20%
Final essay: 25%
Final paper: 20%
Attendance:15%

The grading seems fair. The range of the examinations and essays (both mid term and finals) are quite narrow and almost all of the class managed to score higher than 70% at least. So i assume to SD will be small.
I got a 91% in my mid term essay, a 41/50 (mean: 35/50)

I didn't bother to check my finals, because i got an A- in the end.

So yeah. The course isn't difficult to get at least a B.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is a lot. You'll have to read 60 pages a week of reading materials on average. And it will be especially difficult for those who does not have a strong English background as you will be dealing with complicated words and phrases used by the authors.
However, not to worry, as this is not English Literature, you are only expected to understand the main points that the authors try to convey. The main points from the materials will be discused in the class where Prof DERMAN will provide key questions that needs to be addressed.

So here's my tip for you in the reading materials:
*read the introduction and concluding paragraphs FIRST (this may not be a good idea for stories (spoilers, duh!) but for studies or research it is good. Because these gives you the big picture of the main points the body paragraphs will state. and it made reading easier and faster for me)
*Split the reading materials into smaller chunks and allocate a day for each.


Then you'll have to write a 7 paged analytical essay based on a question DERMAN will provide. The essay will assess your ability to:
*write a thesis statement
*back your viewpoint with evidence from the reading materials
*understand the reading materials

Don't be too frightened by the essays. Yes it will be 7 pages long, but he will ask to to double spaced the lines (without double spacing, it will only be around 3 pages). And as long as you read and understand the reading materials, there will actually be a lot to write about in your essay.
I don't think there's much emphasis on cohesion, grammar, vocabulary, structure, and all the English stuff. But its still good practice to be aware of them.

reviews.author: ReallyYum
reviews.title: A very rewarding course
reviews.comment_content: The content is what you would expect from the course description, which describes the rise and downfall of the Third Reich, and the social interactions, cause, and consequences within it. Mentions of the international perspectives are also given to further complete the picture.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Derman is easily one of the best professors I have met in HKUST. His powerpoints are very well made and he is well-versed in the course materials, often times providing additional information to the content mentioned in class. He would also read every student's paper and give them personal comments, plus spending time for a paper conference to review and see what could be improved.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance 15% (10% from 10 lessons randomly taken and 5% from the paper conference)
Mid-term Exam 20% (50 MCs)
Finals 20% (50 MCs)
Two Paper Assignment (1st 20%, 2nd 25%, both requiring 7 pages)

Got above mean in mid-term and first paper assignment.
Haven't checked the second paper (Late submission resulting in -10 marks) and finals.
Final Grade A- so I guess I should have done well in both of them to cover the loss.
reviews.comment_workload: It should be noted that the workload for this course is not light by any means, it requires you to go through 60 pages of reading per week, where it will be discussed in the tutorial. Though some would argue that you only need to skim through it or just attend the tutorial since the main points will be mentioned in class so you don't have to necessarily go the extra effort. But for your own sake, I would still suggest going through the readings at least once because you would have to use them in your analytical essay. (Yes, external sources are not permitted for reference in the essays.) Besides, the contents of the reading materials would also be tested in both the mid-term and finals (non-cumulative.)

reviews.author: 排骨
reviews.title: Bless this man's soul
reviews.comment_content:
This course teaches the history of the Nazi Party in Germany, detailing specific events and factors that led to the creation, rise and fall of the Party between the end of the first world war to the end of the second world war.
The content taught in this course is well thought-out and organized, and each specific time frame in history is clearly separated and taught, and in the end all linked together.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Great teaching, powerpoints are simple and straight to the point, no long paragraphs that force you to read. Additional and useful supplementary information is also given verbally often to assist us in understand what each particular event is about.
Classes are divided into 2 kinds, lectures and discussion sessions. The discussion session allows the class to sit around and discuss certain events, sharing our interpretations to allow for better understanding (although they might be a bit too frequent, otherwise still interesting enough)
reviews.comment_grading: The mid term exam and finals are ridiculously easy, so no pressure here. Got an A- in the end.
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly readings of texts, and 2 papers (mid-term and final). The weekly readings may seem daunting (60-ish pages per) but its actually not that bad, just skim over them on the bus or something. The papers are also rather straightforward to write so no worries here. Overall workload is fair and should no burden you too much.
